one of the many concerns that continuous integration is trying to solve is first
and foremost it works on my box so that's really what a continuous

gonna be there but when you leave at the end of the day on Friday and come back

in Mexico I don't know you've long forgotten what you were working on it worked before your vacation started and
it's gonna take you even more time to reboot that stuff into your headspace
back into your mental RAM of where you were and what that it was you were working on two weeks ago the longer the
period of time from that last collaboration point the more difficult
that integration step is it's the exact same way with source code it's the exact
same way with taking our text changes in our source code and adding them and
everybody else's text changes it in source code if you last pulled changes an hour ago and it's probably not gonna
be as many merge conflicts as if you last pulled change it's a month ago
that's gonna take you a while to resolve so continuous integration solves a lot
of these problems but there is several elements to what continuous integration is ten specifically first and foremost
is the easy one source control maintaining a source control repository for all of the code it doesn't matter
what the style is doesn't matter if it's good if it's subversion if it's mercurial if it's TFS as long as it's
something that has control that has tracking that has history of that
information of those files source control isn't just a network share somewhere it's gotta be an actual source
control tool a change management tool for all of that all of that text that
we're generating the second element of continuous integration is that needs to
be self building the build has to be automated so some way of
a script let's say something where you can click an icon or execute a command
and it will build the entire application whatever that is if that's a compile if
that's just I don't know transpiling sass into CSS whatever needs to happen
to turn this into an executable thing a runnable thing automating that that
build and along those same lines also automating its testing making the
application self testing some sort of a unit test so that we have an automated
way of validating that the code works that it does what it's supposed to do
and doesn't do what it's not supposed to do now this it's important to note that this self testing element is not based
on TDD it's not a based on test-driven development it doesn't care if you write the test first it doesn't care if you
write the test last as long as there are tests especially since generally your
unit tests and the actual application code that the test covers is going to be
committed at the same time you're probably not going to write a test and commit it and then write the application
code and then commit it or you're probably not going to do the inverse you're not going to write the application code first commit that then
write the test and commit that it's generally going to be all together in one combined commit to your source
control system so it doesn't matter if you write it first or last no association with TDD it's just really
about that test be there that there is some sort of suite of of unit tests to
validate our code number four is frequent merging the original tenant
here so that everyone commits to source control every day I argue that that's
nowhere near enough because a lot can change in the system especially on larger teams if we're only committing
every day this should be at least err and as frequently as possible there's
probably ways that you could commit even more frequently than you already are and
a lot of this is so that we can help eliminate our merge conflicts we merge
frequently we commit frequently so that we can eliminate the conflicts when we're integrating our source code
changes with everybody else's if we were each working on two different features
on a new website I was working on profile management and you are working on authentication we're both going to
need a user class we're both going to go off of email because you're gonna list
the email addresses the as the user name and I'm gonna have the email address on
this profile editing screen we're both going to go off of the same feel but if
we don't merge frequently I'm gonna
create a user class and I might put it in one folder and you might create a

let's say we were going off of the same user class you might create an email
property and I might create an email address property when really we should
both be keying off of the same property but now because we didn't commit
frequently we didn't merge frequently now there's a lot of reintegration steps
to do because I wrote a whole lot of code on one version of email or email address and you wrote a whole lot of
code that relies on the other and now we've got to fix that we can't have two properties we can't have an email and an
email address property we want to make that be one but making one if those properties goes away means that we have
to change all of the code that relies on that property causing a lot of extra work for us just because we didn't
frequently merge we can do this much more commonly than we think much more frequently than when we think the moment
that we create a user class we can commit it it's an empty user class
that's nothing that nothing is using who cares if it's there in the system who cares if it goes to production it's
an empty class that isn't being used by anything in the system it's used by the
developers that are working on the system same way with that email property the moment that email property is
created whether it's email or email address we can commit it nothing's using it who cares if it goes
to production it's not a vulnerability but it does create opportunity for
collaboration on the development team and speeds up that execution time number
five everyone every commit to source control should be built on an
integration machine this really eliminates the it works on my box at
scenario where we forgot to add in the user class we forgot to save the project
file it works on my machine but it's broken on all of your your machines
because I forgot something but we're not gonna find out that it broke on your machine until you've already pulled the
latest changes from source control and now you're dead on the water now the system won't even compile on on your
machine if we compile every single commit on an integration machine this independent integration machine can say
hey J you broke the build and it also will let everybody else know that you
broke the build so that you know not to pull the latest changes you can wait an extra few minutes while I fix whatever
mistake that I made so that I can get the compile going again and it doesn't waste your time it doesn't interrupt
your workflow while you're waiting for me to to fix things now of course that
also relies on number six and continuous integration being informative everyone
can see the result of the latest build everyone knows if the latest build compiles or not everyone knows if the
latest build has tests that pass or not for the developers that means that the
developers know not to pull the latest changes because J made a mistake forgot
to add that user class and the compiled broken give him an opportunity to fix it it lets everybody on the team know it no
let's I Q a know that all of the current unit tests are passing it lets the
project managers know the status of the build maybe even marketing if necessary know the status of the build anybody
that needs to know if the build is working or broken has access to that
information number seven is keeping that process
fast we need to get that feedback as quickly as possible the compile needs to be fast the unit tests need to be fast
we finished up a new feature we've committed that the code changes for our
new feature we've moved on to the next task the next item on the Kanban board
whatever's coming up next is what we're working on and the longer it takes for
us to get to that feedback because maybe we broke the build I made a mistake and
forgot the user class it's harder for me to fix it's more complicated for me to fix if it's a half an hour later my head
is not in the same headspace as I was a half an hour ago or I'm a half an hour into implementing the next feature and I
have code changes for that next feature and it's hard for me to go fix the broken build while isolating it from
these other changes that I also have for what's next so keeping that feedback as
fast as possible helps eliminate that conflict number eight is the application
needs to be distributable making sure that distributable is easy to get by
anyone that needs access to it a good example is perhaps marketing is going to
do a demo today they're going to do to the they're going to perform a demo for the client and they want to show off the
progress that we've made on the application if marketing can easily get
at the latest executable they don't have to come and knock on the developers cube wall or door and say hey J can I
interrupt you for a minute even though I already did can I interrupt you for a minute while you go and create a new
build for me can you create a new executable can you handle a deployment to the marketing environment
I don't know but still some sort of interruption that's gonna happen whether it's marketing whether it's the testing
team giving easy access gets rid of many of those interruptions as far as testing
is concerned full-on testing not just the unit testing a number 9 is that the
system be tested in a clone of the production environment it's close to a clone of the production environment as
possible ideally or an exact replica because then we're testing apples
against apples and there are no surprises when we do deploy this thing this application into our production
environment it's been run through its courses in a production clone so we already know that it's going to work in
a system that's just like this production environment high likelihood that it's going to work in the actual
production environment now I realize that that's not always possible it's not always fiscally possible if our
production environment is a a web form of 50 web servers it might be cost
prohibitive just to have a test environment that also has a web farm of 50 web servers but we can at least go
far as to make sure that every system that's in production has similar systems
in our testing environment so maybe it's not 50 web servers that are on a server
farm that are all load balanced maybe it's 4 maybe it's at least even 2 so
that we know that we're going through load balancing we know that we have to handle things like session affinity
properly we're not testing things like SSL if production has and has an SSL
certificate the test environment should have a valid SSL certificate as well so
we're not testing those elements for the first time in production we already know that the system works just fine
underneath SSL because we've hit that in the test environment and finally number 10 is
automating V deployment so just like we can self compile and self test with the
click of a button or the execution of a command we can do the same thing with our deployment clicking one button or
executing one command from a prompt will completely deploy the application
automatically the benefits of this because the computer is going to execute
that script the same way every time but humans aren't if we have some big ugly
monstrous dance of a script that is deploying to our production environment
from time to time we're gonna miss something from time to time we're gonna
forget to add one of those web servers back into the server farm after the deployment is complete something is
going to go wrong we've all been there where something goes wrong because we've missed one step in the production
deployment now everybody's mad at us the
executive team is mad at us we're working extra late maybe we have to roll back the code roll back the version just
because we missed one little step but by automating the deployment we know it's going to be repeatable we know if it's
going to if we missed in the script adding the server back into the server
farm it's going to forget to do that every single time and we can fix the deployment script and now from then on
every single time we have some reliance then it's going to add the server back
into the server farm so automating that deployment now there's a lot of
